Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Grant: Using modular scaffolding in virtual team projects to develop critical skills in engineering students

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project proposes an innovative approach integrating teamwork and distributed collaboration into the engineering curriculum by using scaffolds supported through information and communication technologies (ICT) to enhance critical skills in engineering students. Some of the specific skills sought include project management, teamwork and leadership. This study incorporates the design, implementation and empirical testing of a virtual team intervention in two project-based engineering courses.

The proposed intervention will be implemented in the context of courses that provide authentic project learning experiences for engineering students through work on real-life engineering problems. This initiative strives to place engineering students one step closer to acting as successful team members and team leaders in multidisciplinary and distributed teams. The funding sought will support the development of a solid program in research and teaching in the area of distributed collaboration and global leadership that can make an impact on critical skills necessary for future engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project used an innovative approach integrating teamwork and distributed collaboration into the engineering curriculum by using scaffolds supported through information and communication technologies (ICT) to enhance critical skills in engineering students, including project management, teamwork and leadership. We designed, implemented and empirically tested a scaffolded virtual team intervention in 5 project-based engineering courses. We found evidence of a significant impact of the intervention on teamwork skills, that is, students that went through the intervention displayed a significantly higher ability to manage team projects than those in the control group. The analysis indicated that students that used the intervention scored 7% on average teamwork skills based on a validated teamwork skills assessment instrument. This difference was statistically adjusted for pre-existing differences in teamwork experience. The follow up qualitative analysis outlined specific elements of the intervention and how they impacted specific collaboration processes. We also gained understanding into the barriers that affect technology use and transferability of the learned skills.

 

Intellectual Merit

The outcomes of this project advanced our knowledge of the development of a critical set of skills for future engineers. The context of implementation included 5 multidisciplinary courses in the engineering college. The courses selected provide authentic project learning experiences for engineering students through work on real-life engineering design problems with a tangible product. The project brought into the classroom state-of-the-art technologies and knowledge from academic and field research to create an intervention aimed not only at improving critical skills in students, but also to be a source of very valuable data to better understand how successful engineering design teams perform. The proposed implementation of educational scaffolds embedded with a collaboration tool is highly innovative and was proven to be a suitable medium for the development of complex skills, such as teamwork and project management for future professional engineers. Our findings also helped determine the role of information and communication technologies in support of collaborative technical work and identify what learned competencies are more likely to be transferred to the workplace and to society at large.

Broader Impacts

This project helped us understand the most effective ways to develop a critical set of skills needed for future engineers working in interdisciplinary projects. Results are facilitating wider adoption of an evidence-based approach to supporting teamwork in the classroom. Instructors teaching project-based courses can easily adopt the modules used in the proposed project. The collaboration tool provides full transparency to the instructor about the work accomplished by students through the project lifecycle. The potential impact is not limited to engineering and could also benefit any areas that seek improved teamwork and project management skills.
